Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54455-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
July 2021 
 
 
 
 
Developing Private Sector Next-Generation 
Renewable Energy Opportunities in Southeast Asia 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BDF  –  Business Development Facility 
  CIF  –  Climate Investment Funds 
  COBP  –  country operations business plan 
  CTF  –  Clean Technology Fund 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  IEA  –  International Energy Agency 
  Lao PDR  –  Lao People’s Democratic Republic 
  PSOD  –  Private Sector Operations Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  Ashok Lavasa, Private Sector Operations and Public–Private 
Partnerships 
Director General  Suzanne C. Gaboury, Private Sector Operations Department 
(PSOD) 
Deputy Director General  Christopher Q. Thieme, PSOD 
Director  Jackie B. Surtani, Infrastructure Finance Division 2 (PSIF2) PSOD 
   
Team leader  Daniel Wiedmer, Principal Investment Specialist, PSIF2, PSOD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  business 
development activities relating to the identification, preparation, and processing of a pipeline of 
private sector high-level technology renewable energy projects. The TA will focus on Southeast 
Asian developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), especially 
Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), Thailand, and Viet Nam, as well 
as  Indonesia,  and  the  Philippines.  The  TA  will  cover  next-generation  renewable  energy 
technologies,  including;  offshore  wind,  green  hydrogen1,  tidal  and  wave  energies,  hybrid 
projects  combining  multiple  technologies,  floating  solar,  integrated  renewable  energy  and 
energy  storage,  grid  or  distribution-level  energy  storage,  other  next-generation  solar  or 
renewable  energy  technologies,  and  smart  grid technologies  (including  demand  response). 
Some of these technologies may have been proven in other markets but have not yet been 
deployed at sufficient scale within ADB’s DMCs, or within the Clean Technology Fund (CTF) 
portfolio. 2  The  TA  will  involve  preliminary  desk-based  market  analysis;  client  outreach; 
preliminary  screening  of  project  opportunities;  development  of  an  investment  pipeline;  and 
preparation  of  further  funding  applications,  project  structuring,  and  ADB  processing.  This 
approach is consistent with the scope for a knowledge and support TA activity because it 
involves a sector-specific search for potential transactions and inputs for project preparation and 
processing. This TA will help build the capacity of ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department 
(PSOD) to identify and process next-generation renewable energy transactions. Opportunities 
for a One ADB approach will be pursued where possible. This could include supporting Office of 
Public–Private  Partnership  initiatives,  or  working  with  ADB’s  regional  departments  and  the 
Sustainable  Development  and  Climate  Change  Department  on  particular  technologies  or 
transactions. 
 
2.  The proposed TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2030, which identifies power as the 
largest infrastructure gap for Asia and the Pacific and includes a strong emphasis on climate 
change. Promoting investment into next-generation renewable energy projects will support the 
commitments to reduce emissions that ADB’s DMCs have made under the Paris Agreement. 
The  TA  is  also  strongly  aligned  with  Strategy  2030  operational  priority  3 (tackling  climate 
change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability) 
and with the following ADB country operations business plans (COBPs).3 
(i)  COBP for Cambodia, 2021–2023, which supports the promotion and expansion 
of renewable energy; 
(ii)  COBP  for  Indonesia,  2021–2023,  which  supports  inclusive,  competitive,  and 
sustainable development in Indonesia, and which will explore opportunities for 
nonsovereign investments; 
(iii)  COBP for the Lao PDR, 2020–2022, which focuses on infrastructure and private 
sector development;   
 
(iv)  COBP for the Philippines, 2020–2022, which has a strong focus on infrastructure 
investment and urbanization to respond to local climate change adaption; 
 
1  Green hydrogen is hydrogen that is produced using renewable energy. 
2  Climate Investment Funds, CTF Trust Fund Committee. 2017. CTF DPSP III Proposal. Washington, DC (15 December). 
https://www.climateinvestmentfunds.org/sites/default/files/meeting-documents/ctf_tfc.20_5_ctf_dpsp_iii_proposal.pdf  
3  ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: Cambodia, 2021–2023. Manila; ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan: 
Indonesia, 2021–2023. Manila; ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 2020–2022. 
Manila; ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Philippines, 2020–2022. Manila; ADB. 2019. Country Operations 
Business Plan, Thailand: 2020–2022. Manila; and ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: Viet Nam, 2020–2022. Manila.

2 
(v)  COBP for Thailand, 2020–2022, which supports private sector renewable energy 
such as solar and wind to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from the power 
subsector; and 
(vi)  COBP for Viet Nam, 2020–2022, which supports lending to support development 
of renewable energy and associated infrastructure. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Energy  demand  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  has  increased  rapidly  alongside  economic 
growth. In 2016, the region accounted for 48% of global carbon dioxide emissions from the 
energy sector.4 Fossil fuel subsidies still exist in many Asian countries, and Asia remains the 
largest region globally for planned, under-construction, or operational coal-fired power plants.5 
Fossil fuel use within the energy sector also causes air pollution, which contributes to growing 
environmental  pressures  and  poses  challenges  to  sustainability,  exacerbating  existing 
vulnerabilities of underprivileged groups. 
 
4.  Current levels of investment in climate mitigation and adaptation in Asia  and the Pacific 
are  insufficient  to  meet  climate  goals.  ADB  estimates  that  meeting  climate-adjusted 
infrastructure needs in Asia and the Pacific region will require $26 trillion of investment from 
2016 to 2030.6 The impacts from climate change already impose significant costs in Asia and 
the Pacific. Reducing the region’s emissions will help reduce the severity of future climate 
impacts and support a more sustainable development pathway. 
 
5.  The United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goal 7 highlights the urgent need to 
increase  renewable  energy  use  and  reduce  the  energy  sector’s  reliance  on  fossil  fuels. 
Transitioning to a green and climate-resilient economy is paramount to ensure that DMCs can 
reduce their greenhouse gas emissions and better hedge against climate change risks. The 
World Energy Outlook 2020 of the International Energy Agency (IEA) points out that although 
policy,  regulation,  and public  finance  will  be  critical  to  give momentum to  a  clean  energy 
transition, most of the investment will need to come from the private sector.7 
 
6.  The  IEA  sustainable  development  scenario for  the  power  sector  estimates that  the 
carbon intensity of electricity generation in Southeast Asia will need to fall from about 571 grams 
of carbon dioxide in 2018 to 118 grams by 2040.8 Although progress has been made globally in 
the deployment of onshore wind and solar technologies, deploying renewable energy at the 
scale required to meet commitments under the Paris Agreement will likely require a variety of 
next-generation technologies. The installation of some of these technologies, such as offshore 
wind and battery energy storage, remain very nascent in Southeast Asia. 
 
7.  Various factors inhibit the deployment of next-generation renewable energy technologies 
within the target countries for this TA, such as; increased first mover costs, lengthy project 
preparation  cycles,  lack  of  government  support,  weak  enabling  environments,  insufficient 
technical knowledge, and a lack of data on the potential resource. As a result, there remains a 
 
4  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
5  ADB and United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. 2019. Asia and the Pacific 
Renewable Energy Status Report. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2017. Meeting Asia's Infrastructure Needs. Manila. 
7  IEA. World Energy Outlook 2020.  
8  IEA. Southeast Asia Energy Outlook 2019.

3 
lack of risk analysis, bankable financing structures or business models, and funding for such 
technologies. 
 
8.  The ongoing global energy transition offers the chance to create new jobs for women in 
science,  technology,  engineering,  and  mathematics  fields,  and  to  reshape  how  energy  is 
produced and distributed to benefit all genders.9 Globally, renewable energy employs about 32% 
women,  compared  to  22%  in  the  energy  sector  overall.  Still,  within  renewables,  women’s 
participation in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics jobs is far lower than in 
administrative jobs. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  proportion  of  power  produced  from 
renewable energy sources in the power generation mix increased and emission intensity per 
unit of gross domestic product reduced. The TA will have the following outcome: investment into 
the deployment of next-generation renewable energy technologies increased.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Thematic and gender-sensitive research and due diligence is conducted 
on certain next-generation renewable energy technologies and transactions. Research will 
be carried out internally, or commissioned from individuals or firms, to understand technological 
risk, resource risk, credit or business model risk, regulatory risk, and other factors that can 
impact project development and bankability for next-generation renewable energy technologies. 
Other factors could include an assessment of the research gaps relating to the bankability of 
new technologies and, where required, market and gender assessments, private and public 
sector outreach (including existing and potential clients), and reviews of existing literature and 
work being undertaken within ADB or by other multilateral banks or organizations. This output 
will help identify a pipeline of opportunities for further nonsovereign processing. 
 
11.  Output 2: Funding applications are prepared, or project structuring, due diligence, 
and  processing  with  gender  additionality  is  undertaken.  Applications  or  investment 
proposals will be prepared for internal or external concessional finance or other climate finance 
sources, and for internal ordinary capital resources processing and approval. More detailed due 
diligence will be undertaken at this stage, including analysis that enables gender measures to 
be identified and incorporated into each project at the time of processing. For energy projects, 
gender elements often include targets for employment, policies, or procurement. During project 
processing, the PSOD’s gender specialists will be part of the project team and will help identify 
and incorporate appropriate measures. 
 
12.  Output  3:  Technology  or  sector  gender-inclusive  reports  or  case  studies  are 
disseminated. ADB will publish reports or case studies on a particular technology, sector, or 
transaction to disseminate knowledge. To the extent possible, the production and dissemination 
of the reports will apply a gender lens including sex-disaggregated data gathering, gender-
 
9  International Renewable Energy Agency. 2019. Renewable Energy: A Gender Perspective. Abu Dhabi. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
sensitive  analysis,  and  gender-inclusive  knowledge  dissemination.  This  will  be  limited  to 
nonconfidential information or information otherwise approved for public disclosure. 
 
13.  Outputs  1–3  will  focus on  business  development,  including  screening opportunities, 
understanding  the  barriers  to  private  sector  participation  and  investment,  disseminating 
knowledge,  conducting outreach to  clients,  sourcing funding,  and  structuring  and  financing 
transactions. 
 
14.  With  the  incorporation  of  gender  considerations  across  the  proposed  pipeline 
development  activities,  the  TA  corresponds  to  the  effective  gender  mainstreaming 
categorization. 
 
15.  TA is proposed because of the emerging nature of the technologies identified in para. 1. 
Because the technologies are still emerging in ADB’s DMCs, the pipeline of potential projects is 
still nascent and will require a combination of focused business pipeline development, due 
diligence, research, and capacity development, in addition to project processing.11 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Clean Technology Fund and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2. 
 
17.  ADB’s Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department confirmed that the TA 
project’s scope is consistent with the ADB proposal submitted to the CTF Trust Fund Committee 
and approved in April 2018.12 Technologies and countries selected are deliberately broad to 
allow  flexibility  to  respond  to  private  sector  opportunities  during  implementation.  The  CTF 
request for proposals for its Business Development Facility (BDF) stated that: 
 
The purpose of the BDF is to provide funding to support [multilateral development 
banks]  and  countries  to  develop  project  pipelines  to  be  financed  by  multiple 
sources of climate finance. The BDF will target sectors and innovative projects 
that face challenges to access climate finance or projects and programs that will 
take an extended time to develop.13 
 
18.  This TA will focus on Cambodia, the Lao PDR, Thailand, and Viet Nam, as well as 
Indonesia, and the Philippines, which are all CIF-eligible countries. The scope will  include 
potential cross-border or regional integration and cooperation projects, to the extent they involve 
next-generation renewable energy technologies. Additional Climate Investment Funds (CIF)-
eligible countries that are also ADB DMCs may also be covered, such as Armenia, Bangladesh, 
 
11 The TA will complement other TA projects such as ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for Promoting Sustainable 
Energy for All in Asia and the Pacific. Manila (TA 8944-REG); ADB. 2021. Technical Assistance for Preparing the 
Pacific Regional Financing Facility. Manila (TA 6619-REG); ADB. 2020. Technical Assistance for Support to the 
Implementation of Strategy 2030 Operational Plans. Manila (TA 6574-REG); and ADB. 2021. Technical Assistance 
for Accelerating the Clean Energy Transition in Southeast Asia. Manila (TA 6744-REG) 
12 Funded through the CTF Trust Fund Committee-approved ADB CTF Private Sector Next-Generation Renewables 
Program, approved by e-mail on 11 April 2018, with a letter of commitment dated 3 May 2018. 
13 Climate Investment Funds, CTF Trust Fund Committee. 2017. CTF DPSP III Proposal. Washington, DC  
   (15 December). p. 18. https://www.climateinvestmentfunds.org/sites/default/files/meeting-
documents/ctf_tfc.20_5_ctf_dpsp_iii_proposal.pdf

5 
Kiribati, India, Maldives, Mongolia, Nepal, Pacific (other eligible Pacific countries under the CIF), 
Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tajikistan, and Tonga.14 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB, through Infrastructure Finance Division 2 of its PSOD, will administer the TA. The 
TA  will  be  implemented  during  August  2021–August  2024.  A  consultant  with  relevant 
experience will be recruited on a full-time basis to lead implementation, and resource persons or 
firms will also be engaged as needed. The consultant will be expected to collaborate with ADB’s 
other departments and divisions to deliver on each of the outcomes described in this TA. 
 
20.  Implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: ADB. 
 
21.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants and carry out the procurement 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
Asian Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of 
$800,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Clean Technology Fund for Developing Private 
Sector Next-Generation Renewable Energy Opportunities in Southeast Asia, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board. 
 
14 Any other CIF-eligible DMCs not listed here may also be covered. A full list of where the CIF invests can be found 
here: CIF. Countries. https://www.climateinvestmentfunds.org/country.

due diligence materials by 31 August 2024.

gender additionality is undertaken

(ii) have an effective  gender mainstreaming categorization by 31 August 2024. 
3. Technology or sector gender-inclusive reports or case studies for knowledge are disseminated 
3.1 Publish the first report, case study, article, or blog by 31 December 2022. 
3.2 Publish the second report, case study, article, or blog by 31 August 2024.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  BDF  –  Business Development Facility 
  CIF  –  Climate Investment Funds 
  COBP  –  country operations business plan 
  CTF  –  Clean Technology Fund 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  IEA  –  International Energy Agency

  PSOD  –  Private Sector Operations Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

Partnerships

(PSOD)

designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.
